8wI6boNIujX5ArdcJd1Pug.text: I think the way to go is to get the fish pie (which isn't all that pricey compared to other dishes) and oysters. As it happens, this wasn't what I was in the mood for these classics when I was there so I had the seafood bisque (delicious) and the salmon cake. The salmon cake was also great, but a bit on the super-rich side. It came with a good, creamy sauce, and sat perched above a bundle of sauteed spinach, which helped cut some of the richness. There was no way I could finish the whole thing.I went at lunch, when it is probably easier to get a booking. There seemed to be a lot of late-lunchers (after 1:30) and the crowd was definitely all business.  A casual tourist in some tennis shoes might not feel right at home.

-zjRf9igfV6NUtQsVjA2Wg.text: Good location for a nice meal if you are staying near Leicster Square.  Oysters were excellent.  Nice seafood and drinks!

8ePsxQ2yLW6MRVgYcnMnjw.text: I stumbled onto this place by accident, via a series of tubes called the internet. I was in London, craving seafood, and something within walking distance from my flat at Trafalgar. J. Sheekey seemed to fit the bill, and I liked the name. I called it, with affection, J. Skeezy. I had the temerity to call at 6:30 on a Saturday night and ask for a table for two. To their credit, they did not laugh at me and hang up, and when I asked if there was anything available on Sunday, they gave me a table at six but said I would have to clear out by eight. This is something that I notice they do in London that is, to my knowledge, fairly unheard of in the states.The J. Skeezy legend grew after I asked a London mate of mine about the place. He said the place was booked well in advance, and when I told him I had a table reserved for six the next evening, he was, as they say, gobsmacked. So my girl and I were stoked about what was to come.J. Sheeky is old school, and old school done right. There is a wealth of oak and walnut restaurants in London--many of which obviously cater to tourists who expect this kind of decor--but the spit and polish on J. Sheeky was exemplary. And the service was equally refined: the head waiter took our order, but the water was poured and dishes were served by an ever-attendant staff of two or three waiters who actually seemed to pay attention to what was going on at our table. This said, I found it odd that were stuck at a very small table for two in the back of the restaurant (by the emergency exit) when there were many open tables that would allowed us to be more comfortable. When we finished our meal and walked out at about 7:45, many of these four-tops were still unused. So much for the legend of this place being booked the the gills.The food was quite good, and also considerably pricey. We started with a dozen Scottish oysters that truly rocked, followed by appetizers: dressed crab (cold Cornish crabmeat served with minced hardboiled egg and a crab mayonnaise) and pan-seared scallops with bacon and baby greens. Both were fresh and perfectly prepared.For entrees, she had the lobster and avocado salad, and I had the whole roasted bream (aka Dorado). Again, these dishes were well-prepared, but nothing to write home about, especially given the prices. I have eaten at many a fine fish establishment where the waiter took a moment to debone to fish. The bream, served head and all, was moist and flavorful, but also packed with bones. I spent a lot of time just trying to remove all the bones. I suppose for some this is considered an enjoyable pasttime. We skipped dessert, opting to wait for the Marks & Spencer bread-and-butter pudding we had sitting in our fridge back at the flat. All in all, I would definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for a solid seafood meal in London, and who is not on a budget. There was certainly nothing wrong with our meal, but there also nothing particularly special about it that would prompt me to give it four stars. Although the food was practically perfect, there was that inexplicable feeling that something was missing.

L28AQ3j7kieMFcLldWff3w.text: This was our first time here and we will definitely be back on our next trip. Fabulous seafood. Loved the oysters. Also had the John Dory and the Dover Sole. Fresh and delish. Service was very good as well. Overheard several other guests saying this was their favorite seafood restaurant.

JS34c2yTR40hlRoJBnCuuw.text: Great seafood. as good as the one i tried in Paris. But no the main dishes. The curry is awful.

KSxHjrAHC02hpI0a895VGA.text: I actually went to the oyster bar, post entertainment.The lady hostess was absolutely useless and originally they sat us in on a corner bar area which was opposite the door.  Result- my legs felt like they were freezing off every time the door opened.  A table became empty so we moved there- now we are looking at the people's butts on the bar; if the girl sat any closer to her partner she would fall off.So far, so not ok.  BUT they have a £15 deal for glass of champers and 6 mercy pearl oysters.  The oysters were so succulent and delicious we ended up having 2 portions each!  Once the hostess left us to be, the waiters are actually super duper nice, knowledgeable and attentive.  We also ate some chips which were excellenet, Dublin Bay prawns which were out of this world.  Dressed Crab and Asparagus were ok, had better elsewhere. I would definitely go there again pre or post theatre, but I will try and book seats so that I won't be frozen or looking at people's butts.

LYkBfVr-5IBWditNZmOWew.text: 0o0o0o0o0o yum city!!LOVE this place....arrived about 15 minutes early for dinner and sat at the bar for a nice lil V & T, extra lime.  The place was fairly empty at about 715 but seriously picked up within half an hour and the place must have been at capacity.  anyhooooo -- the service was fabulous and i had a nice chat with the bartenders while i waited for my friend to show up.the service was impeccable and the food excellent!  we are chronic over orderers and were full after our feast of appetizers but still made room for our grilled fish (i think it was sole but cant remember...whatever it was, it was light and flaky and fabulous) and lobster thermidor -- holy cheesey lobstery goodness.add in a nice bottle of wine and a non-rainy london evening and 4 stars all the way.  extra points in my head for the 80 somethings canoodling in the corner.

gS5azzAh4owehPS1Ep6FtA.text: Took advantage of their weekend lunch offer, first time to Sheekey's and it was absolutely fantastic. Almost felt like stepping back in time with wooden panelling, soft lighting and intimate rooms. Will be going back again and again. Service was excellent, discreet yet attentive and not rushed; atmosphere was very good. I had the Gem Heart Salad to start - short intense blue cheese flavours; the fish pie main - light, fluffy and very filling. The Buttermilk pudding with plums and custard were completely unpretentious. Good spot for a long Sunday lunch to catch up with friends or on a relaxed date.

Q93nVXWicIaG06XC2zcx6Q.text: Yes, the seafood is good. I do love the old-world charm and decor, and the service cannot be criticised. But, seriously, folks -- the prices are not justified. The fish may be fresh and well-prepared, but the markup is staggering and the sides are bland and mediocre at best. In the interest of full disclosure, admittedly I do dine here fairly regularly, but only on expense account or when someone else is treating.

4_DzcyK4-k0Tqzj6wCx46Q.text: Excellent service with superb food, but can be rather loud, making conversation difficult.  A bit pricey (8 pound cover fee) but a treat overall.

hHx-UJ5OwrmJqYKJ4LEDqg.text: I went to J-sheekey with a group of friends, we had previously been to some of the other caprice group resturants so had high expectations.The food did not disappoint, it was delicious and believe me when theres hardly any meat on the menu i am hard to please im totally won over now by the fsh resturant. The ingredients were so fresh and full of flavour, so light that you could just eat more and more.I had great john dorey dsh with clams for main and delilcious scallops with parma ham to start thers also a lovely dessert menu with some great classics such as bakewell tart crumble. The decor wasnt to my taste it was quite classic and typically english,lots of dark wood but there was a great atmosphere and w even spotted the odd celebrity.The food and wine was worth every penny.

ZskZBkpkqGYLLhI2h6YlZw.text: Located near Leicester Square, on a short, narrow street between Charing Cross Road and St. Martin's Lane, this lovely restaurant is known for its seafood options, although they're capable of preparing a rib eye steak, lamb, or duck for carnivores. It's easy to find - just look for the doorman wearing an elegant top hat outside the entrance.The interior is very welcoming, with red leather banquettes and wood-panelled walls covered with photos from the 1940s and 50s.We enjoyed gravlax with marinated cucumber and sauteed scallops with mashed cauliflower as starters, then had fried filet of haddock with crisp chips and mushy peas and curried monkfish and prawns with butternut squash and rice for our entrees. For dessert we shared rhubarb and apple crumble with custard.Our waiter recommended a nice bottle of French white that was a perfect complement to our meal.The food was outstanding, and service was friendly and formal without being fussy. The tab for two, with tip, was £80.On weekends they offer a 3-course menu for only £24.50.Please note that jackets are NOT required, although I would leave the shorts and trainers at home.

JcBMv35R_j5MfLZwqiLgpA.text: This is my favourite place in town. Although it's definitely not a cheap eat it is an impressive date venue. The food is spectacular with out being at all pretentious. Amazing food at the both the bar and at the table. I have had lobster thermador here twice. I could cry just thinking about it. It should be compulsory for all restauranteurs, Maître d's, waiting staff and barstaff to come here just once to find out what good service really feels like. And the interior is delightfully deco. Although the prices may be intimidating, the staff are incredibly down to earth and friendly. Join the mailing list - there are some really good early bird deals being offered at the moment.

m3mg21AvcaI7nwq13EXTrA.text: We visited in October 2011, on a Saturday lunch time, and they were offering 'Saturday specials ' , the choice was good, the food excellent, as was the service.We'll definitely visit we are in London next time.

7aHTmmCKfOSU6YZZOhgwrg.text: Had a really lovely evening last night at the J Sheekey Oyster Bar - where it's possible to book a few days ahead, even on a Friday night - and get away without needing a second mortgage for the bill.What made it so brilliamt was  our Sicilian waiter who couldn't have been more friendly or helpful.I had the fish pie with some steamed spinach on the side - the fish was really fresh (although I could've done with a teeny bit more sauce) - and it wasn't padded out with too much mash. Now for me dinner is all about the dessert - and there isn't a very wide choice at the Oyster bar. Most of it involved some kind of ice cream which I don't like as it hurts my teeth.  I guess most people don't go there for pudding... however the our new best friend the waiter came to the rescue by pointing out the selection of 'brownie, fudge, cookie, eccles cake' which was hidden in with the coffees. I said I didn't really like fudge - and he then came back and offered to substitute it with an extra brownie. Now for £4 I was expecting a couple of teeny squares to arrive - but it was just fantastic - one of the best desserts I've had in ages. Two quite reasonably sized slices of excellent, squidgy brownie - a small, slightly chewy chocolate cookie - and the most gorgeous eccles cake... I've never liked them in the past but this was like a taste of Christmas, lovely, crispy pastry, packed full of currants and some kind of spiced moist, almost marzipan stuff at the centre. Yum. And even on a busy Friday they never once hassled us to give back the table. The nicest service, and the best value meal I've had in a long time.

niG5wWnOy-rQxExnYawLkQ.text: Summary based on 1 dinner:--friendly, attentive service--good seafood, as recommended by the staff--possible to walk in without a bookingI stopped by post theatre hoping for a opportunity to eat at this very well thought of place.  The friendly front end staff was able to accommodate me and gave me a fine seat, not some awful place in Siberia.The waiter's recommendation were quite good as was the accompanying recommended wine.  Recommended, but a proper booking is a good idea.

2PtIWgN-NnD96ltoU4GLdQ.text: I have eaten here 3 times and for 3 memorable reasons. My first visit was for my graduation, 2nd visit was in summer for my anniversary and my third visit 2 weeks ago was for my partners birthday. Each and every visit has been an epic gastronomic treat. They just know how to cook food perfectly. The dover sole is beautiful, as is the roasted shell fish and lobster. I hate oysters but have been told they are sweet and taste of the sea. I have had scallops on all three occasions and have never been left other than gagging for more. The food is always exceptionally fresh and moreish. The wine list is varied and offers complex yet lovely wines and on the Champagne list I would recommend the Billecart Salmon Rose. It's not cheap but it is worth it. For desserts, there is only one dessert as far as I am concerned: Scandanavian Iced Berrries. These iced gems come with a hot white chocolate sauce which is poured over them in a true theatrical fashion. The hot chocolate makes the berries melt and they make their own sauce which leaves you wanting to lick the plate clean. It is a must try if you go there. Getting a table can be a bind but generally if you opt for a day in the week about 3 weeks in advance you should be fine. The food here isn't cheap, but the experience is amazing and you will not visit a finer fish restaurant anywhere else in London.

EUPyMmSn1HkpigBVD4fWiw.text: Had the promotional 6 oysters and a champagne for starters before heading elsewhere to have a carb filled lunch but dem pearl oysters are a malnourished bunch

4cL_GtjG7sS3AV9VKvL0ng.text: average seafood platter for 10x the amount. but at least they give you HEAPSsome of the seafood seemed fake-fresh. had a "taste" to it... service was fab though

UKW_jkp_56KYD-5xqzeWZA.text: This wonderful fish restaurant delivers high-quality, delicious food and the atmosphere is like some of the best Parisian restaurants; you are fairly close to your neighbours but this adds to the ambience.We ate early after a matinee performance on a Saturday and booking the table was easy.

ZklpC07jef7O-N0fTIhEbQ.text: My boyfriend was recommended this place when we asked for seafood and no not fish and chips. Pretty fancy place with the white table clothes.  Lots of theaters and bars/clubs nearby.  We walked in really late which is totally fine as I feel that people in Europe eat dinner super late. The soup we had were really good. The entrees were alright but not as good. Enjoyed it.

CcqdbKGh1oOsSce8Dfhm1w.text: Ate at the oyster bar. The decor was pretty old school classy, not in a cheesy way, and I was into it. Everyone working the bar was helpful, friendly, and humorous.Few tips:-The lobster is very "meh". Get a recommendation for something else.-The way they prepare their octopus dish made me want to request a trough of it. And I'm not a huge octopus eater. ORDER THE OCTOPUS.-Tandoori shrimp is pretty good too

nbOtGdEZIWv9WR3G4Nj1dg.text: Very nice place. We didnt look it up first and just ducked in for quick and light eats. So shared a couple appetizers. Very nice and ambience is high class. Prices go along with that. We were obviously underdressed but the waitress was very friendly and attentive. I would come back for a more proper dining experience if and when i get in thw mood to pay for some quality food served with quality service. Highly recommend as a great date night venue prior to heading to a show!

photos.caption: Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom. The immaculate kitchen opens up to a portion of the dining area.
Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom. Ducked in to get out of a downpour and wound up in a very nice surprise.

MpfTGP7yx4eCsFi9eQol6g.text: Amazing amazing amazing fish restaurant in the heart of Covent Garden! From when you walk in the door you know that your dinner is going to be tasty. As we were early for our reservation (which I recommend you booking) we were seated in the J. Sheekey oyster bar next door.The oyster bar was something out of the 1940's. Silverware, fabric wrapped lemon to wash your hands and an excellent cocktail menu to go with your oysters. We didn't have any oysters as we didn't want to spoil our dinner but from the others whom were ordering them, they looked amazing!We had one champagne cocktail for £9 which is very refreshing, once we had taken a few sips, the waiter moved our drinks onto our food bill next door and took them over to our table waiting for us.We were then greeted by the cloakroom assistant who took our coast in exchange for a ticket, we went to our table and drooled over the menu for 5 minutes.I had a delicious king prawn and cashew nuts waldorf salad and the lobster thermidor for main. Oh my gosh.... THE BEST LOBSTER THERMIDOR I have tasted in a very long time. With my lobster i was offered chips, mash or battered her potatoes; of course i had to the battered her potatoes. It was well worth the £42. To compliment my delicious meal I had two glasses of Prosecco, yum yum! Unfortunately I didn't have enough space for dessert, but more the reason for me to go back again because I'm sure it will taste outstanding.Excellent food, excellent service and wonderful experience!

fLOaI-IZI5QLESqnEv3C1Q.text: I  cannot believe there are not more reviews for J Sheekey, simply the finest seafood restaurant in the known universe.As a Japanese person who despises sushi, (seriously I hate it, raw fish= ugh!)  seafood itself is always a stretch when it comes to culinary experiences. That is until I had my holy grail meal dining at J Sheekey.  Before my trip to London, I'd researched some notable London restaurants and J Sheekey kept popping-up, also I was suckered into making a reservation as I'd heard that David Beckham & Micheal Caine are frequent visitors, no sightings of the celebs upon dining there of course but I saved making an ass of myself whist gawking at Becks and drowning in my own salivary fluids so it's just as well...Upon arrival we are greeted by a doorman and ushered inside, the ambiance is the usual masculine touches of wood and leather, dimly lit with autographed photos of various Brit celebs of yesteryear littering the walls. The patrons seemed mostly business men with clients, and couples. We got seated next to the table with an inebriated, loud mouth and his mail-order girlfriend but we were soon pacified by the sumptuous food.Our handsome French (nice!) waiter suggests we start with the Fines de Clair oysters so hubby indulged in 6 and soon doubled his order to 12 as he downed them like a kid downs his first taste of jello shots. Hubby claims they are indeed the best oysters ever had and coming from his Canadian East Coast upbringing he's got the seafood savvy to back that up.Next I order the Scallops with mash while hubby indulges in the 22oz Dover Sole. The scallops literally melted in my mouth (mmmmouthgasm!) and are complimented perfectly with the mash which is light fluffy and neither too buttery nor too dry. Hubby is wide eyed in appreciation of his Dover sole and sadly shakes head and claims he'll probably never get fish this fresh and delicious back in Toronto... To close out this savory symphony we have the Pimms Jelly ring with peaches and Scandinavian Iced Berries with hot white chocolate for dessert...ecstasy ensues... If you are a skeptic of seafood and find yourself in London craving an excellent meal, please visit J.Sheekey and indulge in their gorgeous seafood...Red Lobster will never suffice again...

PVxD_-kLIVPhBSjXlEGuiQ.text: Stumbled upon this place and wow what a find! No reservation, so we sat in the Oyster Bar section. Amazing fresh seafood and exceptionally knowledgeable wait staff. This might be my new favorite restaurant in London!  Right there in the middle of everything!

hBt0Mepf1Wl5TMLDjScxnA.text: An out-of-town friend and I went to J Sheekey because I was in the mood for seafood. It was extremely busy so we ended up at the oyster bar instead of the restaurant. The oysters are amazing. The champagne is superb, The wine list is incredible (definitely worth coming back to just for the wine list). The crab bisque soup is exquisite. The prawn and avocado salad is oh-so delicious. By the time we got through the first page of the menu, we were too full to order a main dish. Sitting at the bar meant you have the attention (and service) of the bar tenders. It's great if you can't decide on all your dishes in one go.The decor of the restaurant is warm and inviting. Classy but not overly. The wood panelling and small rooms make the restaurant feel intimate and inviting. A great place to catch up with a friend over a decadent meal.The meal was extravagant and indulgent. It's best to go in, start ordering, and don't look at the final bill when you leave. Your stomach will thank you for it.

qIvslsrbUHPSCMlDs8hzAw.text: Visited the evening of 29 November 2015.  Tempura fried oysters starter was great (but the listed wasabi in the sauce wasn't evident).  The grilled salmon were top notch.  But the service (on the bar/casual side) during this visit was terrible.  The kid who was the server didn't have a clue: it took 15 minutes after ordering to get an Old Fashioned', he got the ordered entrée wrong, (!, another 10-12 minutes for them to get it right), and the requested dessert menu never came, (after another 15 minute wait for this the maître de noticed and brought me a menu - but by then I was in no mood to order).  They add an automatic 12.5% tip - which for this server was so NOT worth it.  Consider with caution.  Hopefully service will be made right.

A-u-440AgKjjzllBxbpTAw.text: I came in for a later dinner here (10 pm). The food was good but was stuck out was the service. It might be some of the best service I have received in London. I didn't try a lot of dishes but I had the salmon which was perfectly cooked. I had veggies as a side and they were excellent too. The atmosphere here is lovely. The best part was definitely the service. A little pricy, but I'd like to go again.

qAUDheFidinVKQ2TzWNV2w.text: Quite possibly my favorite seafood restaurant in the world ... Old school vibe, amazingly fresh seafood and great service. Get the Dublin bay prawn appetizer!

GqrZfY9OIjUOXoPSJDeO2g.text: Best seafood in London and comparable to the best in the world.  I recommend sitting at the oyster bar where you can select from 1/2 dozen oysters and small seafood plates to share.  The decor is quite pleasant and the service makes you feel like you are the owner.  Hands down a must go, don't let the prices hold you back from indulging yourself.

ymKjE63t9kqGHE_sJZAhNA.text: Leicester Square is normally an area in London, which I avoid. It is the heart of tourism and there is no sold to it, as this is the meeting point of everybody but  belongs to nobody!Saying that I found myself there one night looking for a classy place to dine. Walking past the tube station there is a small alley with pubs. There I spotted the comedian who acts in 'Little Britain'.Furthermore, walking down the alley there was an elegant restaurant called J.Sheekey. In 1896 a seafood market stall-holder, Josef Sheekey, was granted permission from Lord Salisbury  to serve fish and seafood in his new building development in St Martin's Court. Upon the condition that he supplied meals to his lordship's private post-theatre dinner parties, J. Sheekey, the restaurant, was born.If you look for a pst-theatre dining in an elegant ambiance, this place has the best fish speciality, let alone their oyster bar. This place is expensive but very special and has all the british style and taste. A doorman opens even the door for you.
