h8SQ7NFhDQS1GxgbFK_WaQ.text: Outstanding  well worth the value.  Service was excellent! The Plateau de Fruits de Mer was a seafood overload.  Ask for John Andrews , grout house manager,  he is just superb!We will be back!

A622Qan7xqGIvQlJoRJ5QA.text: Restaurants come and restaurants go. But Sheekeys is always there and always brilliant. In fact, as a Londoner born and bred I can honestly say that this is in my top three all time London restaurants. Ooh. That's a big call. There are literally hundreds and hundreds of great places to eat in this amazing city. I've been to restaurants that serve better food (although frankly, not that many). I've been to a couple of places where the service was somehow more impeccable. I've been to places even more charming than this beautiful location. And I've been to places with even more of a buzz about them. But there isn't a place that combines all of the above so beautifully and to such a consistently high standard.I have been here many times over many years and have never had anything but the most wonderful meal. And so it was again last week. On edge and panicked after watching Argo at the Empire we dived into sheekeys to gather ourselves!This famous fish restaurant, over 100 years old, is tucked away in a charming alley off Shaftesbury avenue and a top hatted doorman suggests a pompous air which never materialises once inside. The buzz as you walk into this 100 year old restaurant is great. The restaurant is always choc full. Couples. Families. Business dinners. Pre-theatre. Tourists. Locals. Young. old. The place attracts everyone. And they are all here for a good time. Sheekeys is split into four rooms, all with their own little nooks and crannies. you could be in a Dickens novel when you sit down. Tables are comfy but tight. There is dark wood everywhere and framed photos of all the stars of film and theatre adorn every spare bit of wall. It's great fun just to stare at them and work out who some of the more obscure ones are. We're slap bang in the middle of theatre district and sheekeys has always catered to that crowd.The bread that arrives is gorgeously chewy and moist inside. Always gone before the first course appears.The menu is a joy. Sublimely simple dressed crab, herring and potato salad, griddled squid, mussels in a spicy soup, gradvalax, razor clams, it's all there. None of it disappoints. No fanciness called upon. Just utterly Fresh fish and crustaceons served expertly by friendly, efficient staff.I went for the queen scallops and cockles in a delicious winey sauce and it was divine. Main courses are more of the same. Simple classics accompanied by beautiful sides. Dover sole at eye watering prices, or warming fish pie at a snip. The Cornish stew is special. There's even meat if you're brave enough to ask. I saw two great burgers go out of the kitchen. But most people are there for the fish.We decided to go for the sea bass for two. A wonderful specimen baked in salt was presented to us whole for our approval. We approved. Off they went to fillet it. And back it came, expertly deboned and resplendent with a copper pan of fennel in a delicious hollandaise type sauce as accompaniment. We also ordered chips, crispy, light and fluffy and sheekeys own courgettes in Parmesan which are evil but delicious crispy rounds of courgette that you could eat forever. Everything is cooked to perfection. If we could fit a pudding in we would but we can't so we don't. It's not cheap, that's for sure. Our sea bass was £64. That's a lot by anyone's standards. But it was worth it. It really was. And as I said you can eat there at far more reasonable prices if budget restricts.For consistent brilliance this place gets the full five stars. It's hard to imagine going to a restaurant so many times and always being thrilled with the whole thing but that's been our experience of this national treasure. Book up now. Get in the queue. You won't be disappointed.A quick tip. If you can get a table ask if there's room at their beautiful sweeping bar. You can eat there and if its just the two of you, it's actually  really rather fun sitting there.

UsWZXuOPAO-7XAy6SURqGg.text: We turned up without a reservation and were welcomed with attentive, careful service. No tables being available we were offered seats at the bar, but my wife didn't fancy that. Our gracious host immediately whisked us next door into the charming Oyster Bar and settled us in a cosy corner table. We really were treated like valued regulars rather than random walk-ins and that set the tone for an absolutely fabulous evening. Starting with the best champagne I've ever tasted we munched our way through a selection of some of the best seafood I have ever tasted. Fresh and cooked to perfection there was nothing to be faulted. Rich, thick home-made mayonnaise was the perfect compliment to crisp pommes allumettes. But the best of the best was a little dish of octopus with chorizo and beans. This was out of this world and quite the best octopus preparation I have ever tasted. The waiter explained with huge enthusiasm that the dish is cooked "sous vide" in seawater for three and a half hours at a low temperature. It was worth every minute. Dessert was a wonderful traditional steam pudding and custard, which I rounded off with an excellent espresso. One of the best meals I've ever had the pleasure of eating, and I have been lucky enough to eat in many fine restaurants.

PZcPXaJYqHg3Uf-I37jujA.text: Oysters and Boar Sausage were amazing. Squash salad, octopus salad was ridiculously good and the frozen berries and hot white chocolate was out of this world!

iycROg-vTqrj817_qmrjwQ.text: Seriously impressive. 'You're a seafood lover, so you're biased' I hear you cry! Yeah I am, get over it. Or just go to J Sheekey and see for yourself...Started with a drink in the bar area whilst we waited for our table to be ready and treated ourselves to a delicious apple sherry. Certainly strong enough to relax us and we soon forgot we were in swanksvillle surrounded by the haves and the have-mores.The seafood (and let's face it, it's pretty much all they do) is fantastic - with such a range of choice. Our friends went for the huuuuge seafood platter to share and I just couldn't believe the size of the thing (over two tiers) - my jaw dropped. Once I'd finished my razor clams I got stuck in to help them out. The oysters were delicious.Our mains were just as good, and I'm a big fan of the courgettes side dish. Fresh fish and lobster, beautifully cooked and presented and a real pleasure, treat to eat.Didn't have space for dessert but they sounded scrumptious.I don't know when I'll get back here - bookings are hard to come by and it's far from cheap, but when I do, it's going to be a real treat for me and the lucky person I drag with me.J Sheekey FTW.

0fFK31FeYTAuZ6OM6v4ygA.text: Wow.  Another great restaurant in London near the St. Martin in the Fields church.  It's tucked away in a little alley way and it seems to be separated by an oyster bar and the restaurant.  We had reservations at 7:30PM and didn't end up there until 7:50PM because we got lost looking for it due to the detour we had to take.  The reason?  The London premiere of the movie "Salt". Apologies to Angelina Jolie, but we had already seen the movie and J Sheekey was more worth visiting that night than the cinema.We had actually wanted to go to the restaurant on a Sunday night, but the person we spoke to on the phone said there were out of, "cod, sea bream, salmon, oysters, etc".  I was like, "Holy cow, what did they have left?"  So we ended up going there Monday night when they had apparently gotten a new delivery of seafood.And boy, was it worth the wait.  We ordered:Roasted Cod with herbsHerb Roasted Gilt Head BreamSide of roasted squash and broccoliThe cod was tasty, but the star of the meal was the Gilt Head Bream.  It's the whole fish that comes out with the herbs stuffed in the cavity.  Just really fresh fish at its finest.  The lowest point of the meal for us was the broccoli.  It's a matter of preference I think, but the broccoli was overcooked.  Limp, almost mushy, and lifeless.We were so full we did't get any dessert this time, but reserve ahead, because J Sheekey is not in need of business, that's for sure.

X3CLgIDeVD7ptVxxyKPFww.text: For photos see Greedy Diva @ greedydiva.blogspot.com/…  Despite there being so many new and interesting restaurants popping up in Covent Garden, it's also nice to visit one of the more old school establishments every now and then. Lunch at J Sheekey was just the ticket. The old timer at the table next to us remarked to the waiter that her mother had brought her to J Sheekey as a young girl - and it feels like that kind of place. Black and photos of theatre starlets line the mahogany panelled walls. The long standing appeal of the place comes down to its history, effortless style, seamless (if a little stiff) service and well sourced ingredients executed properly. As part of the Caprice Holdings group (which includes stalwart establishments, The Ivy and Scotts), J Sheekey is predominantly a fish and seafood restaurant, and the best of its offerings is probably not on the set lunch menu that we opted for. The plateau de fruits de mer for 2 people looks stunning. However, the weekend lunch menu, at £26.50 per person for 3 courses, is probably the best means to get away lightly in what is otherwise a pricey restaurant. Gravlax with marinated cucumber and a Swedish mustard dressing was a small but silky starter, while my fabulous, tender grilled squid perched atop a sweet, nutty red pepper sauce. J Sheekey has a reputation for its fish pie - and while it's not as unctuous as the one you'll find at Bentley's, it is creamy and comforting, and laden big chunks of salmon and prawns. There's a satisfyingly thick and crispy layer of potato on top, although my pie was lacking in white fish. Since they had run out of salmon, TPG enjoyed the rich feast that was the grilled chicken with buttered cabbage and earthy wild mushrooms - a terrific, hearty option if you don't want fish. The clementine sponge pudding with warm custard is gorgeous - the perfect wintry dessert. The pretty raspberry ripple ice-cream was not as impressive, but the boozey cherries gave it a lovely kick and it came with a fine, crisp shortbread. J Sheekey also offers a fish and chips and glass of house wine deal for £16.50, and it's worth keeping in mind as a pre- or post theatre option, being in the heart of West End theatre land. You could also try the J Sheekey Oyster Bar next door, which is always bustling - reservations at either the bar or restaurant can be hard to come by, so plan ahead.

vWZbd2TsAiEatnUA6bySYg.text: First time here, on the recommendation of a friend who's a massive foodie. We were taking a client, and it's a good spot for that - felt a bit too formal before it got busy, but by the end of our lunch (2.30 ish) it was nice and noisy. Wood panelled comfortably small dining rooms, an older and professional clientele. Nice location, nice ambience. Service was good, although our main very slow in arriving after starters were taken away. That was a shame but not a huge spoiler. The food was good but not outstanding or memorable. We had oysters to start - delicious - and then one of our group had Pollack, one Monkfish steamed, and I had Ray Wing, which was very interesting and tasty. The veg sides were a little disappointing - the mash was a bit smash-y, carrots very tasty but perhaps one degree too al dente but the spinach (I think) creamy thing was very good indeed. Our waiter recommended a fantastic minerally white wine to set the fish off, and all was generally well in the world. I'd definitely go back. It just didn't elevate me onto another plane, at least not this time round. But certainly good enough.

I559CMXuOsffc_sz60jbfg.text: I wanted to like this place based on the menu and location so booked a lunch here for my birthday.  Everything we had was mediocre.  We are from New Orleans, LA  USA so I can say with confidence that we know good seafood.  I did not like the razor clams at all.  Bisque was just ok, fairly tasteless.  Nothing to write home about.  Our waiter seemed put out that he had to work.The building is very interesting.

EUXs42YZkBhm2gSyPNUcCQ.text: We were in the mood for seafood and especially wanted to check out local oysters so we chose this place for our pre-theater dinner. We reserved in advance on their website to be sure we could be in and out in time for our show. It was excellent! We're not fans of white wine or champagne so we tried the cocktails (midsummer night and elysium) and they were so lovely and went with the food. We shared the mixed oysters and sausages to start (wonderful) then hubby had the night's special (sea bream) and I had the fish stew. We also shared the spinach side. Tacky tip, but be sure to have to visit the loo to check out the pictures along the stairway to the lower level.

qdxXk1hGmL641KUp0vTPGQ.text: We tried this restaurant and found it just satisfactory. The razor clams were good, the Bibb salad with hazelnut was good, the flat iron steak with prawns was tasteless, and the crab bisque was very disappointing.I expected more from a restaurant charging as much as they did. I wouldn't go back. I wouldn't recommend this restaurant either.

wXlPLnhqJEv1qo1PwV5ukQ.text: We booked into this historic restaurant with high expectations of good service and seafood....our expectations did not match our experience.The setting and the ambience inside the restaurant were good. A pleasant and  formal welcome, and then off to the bar which was where we were seated to dine from....our server was Will B..... and we were presented with menu's and the wine list....An efficient and pleasant start...we both ordered the Squid as our entrees and for mains the Fillet Plaice and Dover Sole were our selections...with some accompanying side dishes. The bottle of wine came and we sat comfortably with expectations...The squid was good and the Pinot too....and from then on the night degenerated....The Sole came first and we waited for the Fillet...we waited, and waited....when some 8 minutes later it came the Sole was morphing on being luke warm....no apologies came though! We raised the matter and begrudgingly we received a half apology from Will. Still the side dishes had not arrived. We enquired and Will disappeared to then return and explain that 'someone' had made a mistake in the kitchen and that he had now cancelled the side orders. He then realised that the night was off track when he noticed we were social media users 'on Yelp'...so then came the 'buy offs'... the offers of free drinks, desserts etc. We declined, we paid the bill and departed.We will not be back...now I know no-one is perfect and mistakes are a part of life....the difference is how they are managed so with good manners and openness mistakes can be accepted. Not though when they are not willing to be opening acknowledged or when the rescue is by trying to 'buyoff' the customer. This under mines the integrity of good dining and restaurants. Well it may have been a 'one off or bad night'...with behaviours like this I hope so....!

sFwQjumr6sUQe4ntTD1CJw.text: One of the best dining experiences I have had in London. Seamless service, amazing food, and a classic venue. Well known for their sea food, all items are fresh and expertly made. Creative, interesting desserts. We started with a dozen oyster and then I had the shrimp burger (to die for, you don't really need the bun) while my dining partners had the shellfish platter, which they generously offered to share. For dessert we split the Chocolate Honeycomb Bom. By far, the best dessert I had recently, on par with the Pineapple Cake at Hestons.Well worth it for a special occasion, classic London.

uCkkf1mjZO8sxLjjsVOfjg.text: Wonderful seafood fish restaurant, very casual.  Fish was fresh and wonderfully prepared. Service good!

iX01TBWygssYjUiRZhNpVA.text: Best meal we had in London this trip.  We had Dover Sole with Bearnaise, steamed spinach, tomato salad and apple pie with custard.  Each dish was excellent as was the service.

uzT6nwj9f2FmLr8LzEONYw.text: My friend and I came to the Oyster Bar last night for a catch up over some seafood and wine. I really like the bar area - it has a separate entrance and there is the option of either a table or sitting at the bar, but I thought sitting at the bar was a lot more fun and perfect for groups of 2-3 people. The staff recommended 2 small dishes per person, and on top of that we got 3 oysters each. Our waitress was very knowledgeable and explained to us the distinctions between the two main types of oysters, either delicate or strong/fishy. We opted for the former and she directed us to exactly which ones to order. The oysters are served on a platter with a lemon wrapped in gauze (very nice touch, to catch the seeds from falling out), and two lovely shallot vinaigrettes, one of which has a little bit of spiciness. We then had our two cold plates, the bass ceviche and the buffalo mozzarella. Both were amazing. The bass came with plentiful helpings of avocado and the meat was very light and tender, and I didn't taste jalapeno at all. I could not get enough of the buffalo mozzarella... the pesto really did it for me, and luckily we had a basket of bread to help finish it all off, as the two crouton crisps on the plate were definitely not enough. Our two hot plates were the flat iron steak with prawns and the griddled octopus, which I also very much enjoyed.  All in all, it was a lot of food! Of course none of this comes cheap, and the picpoul I had by the glass was also £10/glass, so the damage was quite considerable. But for excellent seafood and great atmosphere, J Sheekey is well worth a visit.

8DuGSG8u3fgAozO944Dekg.text: I've had J Sheekey on my list of go-to restaurants for several years now, so it was only fitting that my first dinner in London was at this celebrity hot spot! First off, service is impeccable and you will interact with several waiters and waitresses. For appetizers, I would highly suggest the beetroot and goat cheese salad and the gravlax. For my main, both times I dined at J Sheekey, I had the pan fried salmon which came with its own carafe of bubbling brown butter. I almost thought nothing could top that, but I was wrong because the desserts are even more sinfully delicious. I've tried the Cox's Pippin Apple Pie, the Sticky Ginger Pudding and the Rhubarb Crumble. You will always be offered a cup of custard to drizzle over your warm desserts and you'd be stupid not to take them up on this offer. I'm still dreaming about the two dinners I've had here! J Sheekey is a classic chic British restaurant and worth making reservations far in advance to score a table, don't miss out!

4pZt3Qk5T9tjVT_Fb7w2Vg.text: Was back here for dinner... Wow, what a horrible place it has become. Tables have been always quite small and settings just is not pretty - all of these have been there and nothing much changed.., what changed dramatically is good.., I tried razor clams, shrimp and sardines and my dad tried grotto misto and salmon. They were all very underwhelming..., first temperature of hot food is all off - food is slightly cold by the time they reach the table. Secondly sea food / fish are not fresh. I am not sure how this is possible in such high traffic seafood restaurant but it is possible... I could not eat my fish.., gave it to my cat later. How sad to see such a legendary restaurant turning into this tourist trap. Sadly, I probably would not go back for a few years until things change dramatically here...

bKJYHNR1_5HFBTuMU9ljCQ.text: We were looking for a place to sit outside, have a snack and slake our thirst after a long day of sightseeing and ran into this elegant seafood dining establishment in the theater district.  Not being exactly dressed for it, we were somewhat hesitant to enter but were greeted enthusiastically and seated at an outdoor table.  The menu has an extensive selection of seafoods including an raw bar, much of which is quite pricey.  We selected their daily special of 6 oysters and a glass of champagne for £16.75, probably the cheapest items on the menu.  And although it was obvious that we were not prepared to spend a lot of money that day, the waiter was very friendly and in no way made us feel uncomfortable.  The oysters and the drink were delicious.  At one point I went inside to the bar area to get a better wifi signal and the bartender came over with nuts and olives to go with the champagne glass that I had carried with me.Based on the excellent food and gracious service, I would definitely return when I'm looking for a more complete meal.

OJMSuC1KtWs3U7i7dkTt8w.text: First restaurant we went to after landing in London town. I must say with being jet lagged with no sleep the night before, I made it through with delicious food from here.We had a huge tray of fruits de mer. Half of the seafood I didn't even know existed! Razor clams were great and everything tasted so much more fresh than anything I've tried in NYC. It really opened up a new perspective on seafood for me, especially since I usually get hesitant on trying new things.Service was superb!!! We also had a dessert with our lunch special. It had an orange elderflower sherbet which I loved.I'll gladly come back here when I'm in town again.

2FFmPc9SOzVPvtCBd57LvA.text: Came here tonight for dinner and absolutely loved the razor clams appetite and mixed shellfish grill entrée! Also ordered the monkfish plate as well but preferred the shellfish grill a bit more :) Definitely would love to come back to try other dishes.  :)

jLclup4uHabaKXC29EJ4WA.text: Incredible food, incredible service and an old school ambiance that won't quit. We came here after a terrible start at another place and we were not disappointed in the least with this legendary establishment. We were seated in one of the cubby like rooms somehow feeling cozy but not cramped. Service is attentive but not cloying, and watching the waiters expertly maneuver the dumb waiters is pretty fun. But the star of the show is the food - totally old fashioned recipes like pickled herring, and cream,  razor clams with fava beans, and grilled fish with Béarnaise sauce come alive and seem modern because of the simple preparation and exceedingly high quality of the ingredients. The grilled turbot was in my top 5 fish experiences ever!

YSa8eLTvw2UwuPZ_U_4rSg.text: Going to J Sheekey for their fruits de mer platter is for me the equivalent of walking into a spa. A brief respite of pure unadulterated luxury, a heady healthy hit that generally goes a long way towards improving my state of mind. The definition of a treat in other words. It hasn't changed here in years, an I mean that in a very good way. Nicco Polo and I settle into a luxurious banquette with a self-satisfied sigh entirely at evens with the surroundings. Acres of luxurious linen cloths, a friendly and superbly well drilled FOH team and an awesomely good selection of shellfish. Nothing else needed.Given my frothing tone so far, I should stress that while Sheekey is luxurious, there's nothing pretentious about it. Seeing that we were struggling and wasting time with the faff of peeling the succulent little brown shrimp, our waiter gave a handy seaside tip, pinching head and tail together to pop out the sweet, fresh goodness. If I were a newbie contemplating attacking a platter, then this level of thoughtfulness would be even more appreciated.If there's something vaguely erotic about the eating of an oyster, then fruits de mer is the culinary equivalent of no holds barred, hanging from the lampshade sex with a fruity, nubile and entirely innapropriate ex. A plethora of succulent, juicy little nubbins, blushing creamy pink morsels and taut sinews, each begging to be sampled next. Like the aforementioned illicit tryst, there's a wild menu of differnt styles, types and positions, everyone has their favourites and it's all so borderline lewd that nobody wants to imagine their parents at it.After that, an ice cold buttery white wine and something to mop up the juices (see, I said you didn't want to imagine your parents at it...) we collapse back into the banquette. Perfect, absolutely perfect.

a4R6RAr9HSfsAaEXn6qKug.text: Possibly my all time favourite restaurant. Yes, you will empty your wallet for a meal here, but it's worth it. Think upwards of £600 for 4 people. My favourite dish is the seafood platter which includes lobster, razor clams, prawns and scallops - irresistible! Every bite makes you feel bad for people who are allergic to shellfish; they'll never be able to experience the heaven that is the J Sheekey seafood platter. While simply put together the quality of the fish and the subtly of the flavours makes every moment memorable. The decor is charming as can be. Wood panelling, vintage photographs, thin glassware, lovely china and soft light gives you a sense of age, class and warmth. The service is impeccable - waiters are neither in your face nor absent. It's service that you just don't really notice which is my favourite. You have everything you need when you need it, and are left to just enjoy yourself.

8KMkDkmi5p8huFpPkuKZ4A.text: You'd better like seafood, but if you do, this is a great place to experience it.The restaurant feels like an institution: a top-hatted doorman greets you, and the walls are plastered with celebrity photo endorsements. More wait staff per table than I think I have ever encountered, which made the entire restaurant feel bustling, almost urgent.As for the food, I had a shrimp and scallop curry, which had a great balance of flavor with a nicely placed sharp sour cream. My husband had the special fish, which we both agreed was good, but not outstanding.We would return, but I don't think it stayed with us the way some of our other London restaurants did.

qIxLW__wA9qj6v3ydIUk9g.text: The best seafood restaurant I have had the pleasure of enjoying.  Our party of 8 would agree this was one of the best meal we had over a week of eating at several London restaurants.  After having Dover Sole on two previous occasions, theirs was by far the best.  They serve it as a 16oz or 22oz portion, the 16oz is plenty.  The one negative for me, was they sat a large gentleman directly behind me and the wait staff frequently bumped my chair.  The space can be too tight.  In light of that, we all agreed we would definitely return in the future.

Jb1x2DpSr5eyTgyWv6f3yw.text: I find this place a real treat, whether taking visitors or a small group of local friends.  The seafood is phenomenal, and I appreciate their small plate approach, so sharing is easy.  They also pour a mean martini.

eI5jCdxVugT_AxsSCyCN_w.text: I like the scene here; you can feel like you are part of thecompany, from preparation of the ingredients up to cooking, and most of all,eating. The ambiance was really entertaining. We loved watching the cookspreparing our foods. The food here is truly delicious that is why many peoplecame here every day. The service of the staff here is excellent too. All thestaffs are super friendly and skilled hurrying up and down delivering foods toall the customers and I gained some cooking tips while seeing them. The food is truly wonderful and theenvironment as well.

vYQX04r3XKeQ8n81NXqOkA.text: I came to London on vacation and this is probably the worst experience I've had yet. To begin, I'm staying at the Ritz. Days before we arrived in London they made a reservation at Sheekey and to my surprise when I got into the restaurant, they said they were giving us seats at the bar. You would assume they saved a table for us. We then asked for a table and they seated us directly next to where the wait staff meets. They barely paid us any attention, and to make matters worse my mother's fish was undercooked. When she asked for a glass of wine they gave her one with about two sips worth in it, and didn't show her the bottle. My crab bisque had all of two pieces of crab in it, and overall the place was sub par.

X_mBz-M7JKvhVAYGl-lsUg.text: J Sheekey is an institution that could easily ride on its name recognition, serving mediocre food to tourists who may never return, but far from it they serve some of the freshest and best prepared seafood in town. I dined at J Sheeky over ten years ago with my grandfather and recently returned there on a trip with my husband. The restaurant was as cozy and comfortable as I remembered and the food was still excellent. My husband started with oysters and I had tuna tartare. Both were clean, fresh, and delicious. The server also provided excellent information about the different oyster options. For our main courses, my husband ordered dover sole and I ordered cod. Both were excellent, but the quality especially showed in the seafood risotto underneath my cod. It was full of plump, fresh shellfish and absolutely delicious. I had to fight my husband off as he kept trying to dig in to my plate! For dessert, we shared a dish of ice cream (cherry swirl--Mmmmmmm!). There were lots of good wines by the glass, so we started with a glass of champagne and then had chablis with our mains. It was a lovely evening with delicious seafood. What more could we want?I see some other reviewers had issues with service. We had a reservation and our table was waiting when we arrived. Our service was excellent--there when we wanted someone, but never overbearing. No issues or concerns whatsoever in this regard.

MAHdOQZ2oHVtOSdn-V-A1g.text: Dover sole and John Dory. That is all. Simple. Amazingly executed. Fresh. Fast, efficient service. Not overbearing.

k1ACjM1L3zYMlPBquT0goA.text: In general: Excellent service from knowledgeable and attentive staff. No request seemed to be a problem with a dietary need from the table next to me given proper attention. Wheelchair access was not a problem. Water was topped up regularly and there was two types of warm house made bread.Food: My octopus starter had Spanish flavours and came with soft skin-on red baby potatoes and marinated red capsicum. The entire dish had gentle heat from the chillies with lemon and other flavours making my only disappointment that I had no more to eat! Enough for a light main but not too big for a starter. I then had the fish pie with a side of tender but still wonderfully slightly firm heirloom carrots cooked in oil with pistachios.  The pie had three types of fish including thick flaky salmon. Fat chunks of fish were not dominated by the tasty creamy sauce.  This was covered in a perfectly ratioed layer of mash flavoured with mustard and baked until crunchy on top. The perfect fish pie. I could eat this every week. Dessert was a difficult choice of 'yumminess'. The only measure of a dessert! I ended up with a gorgeous shortbread, caramel popcorn and praline slice with milk icecream.  A champagne, chardonnay, starter, main and dessert plus a hot chocolate was only £83. I highly recommend this place for a perfect foodie experience.

ZrlODvR23SOkES0x1-jT0A.text: Awesome sea food. Pricier than a simple night out, but worth it. Great service at bar and food is super good.  Must go. Theater crowd or date nite. Always a good choice

VcBu7DjA5lr2NKPBDW1OJg.text: If you want oysters in london, this is the place to go. They basically educated me on oysters. Other seafood is good too, but that's not really why you're here.

1Qw3IYVQAVLSuRn3uCc1jw.text: In this very best seafood restaurant, it re-activated my appetite for the oyster, lobster, mussels and nameless types of shellfish. Before that, I used to believe I had enough with seafood, I simply hate the smell of sea water. I am converted ;)

Z3TfRO-7XKmNDM3n53KGOg.text: A London Institution.lived up to its billing as the best Fish restaurant in London.I had a half pint of prawns, followed by a whole Brown Crab. Not food for a first date.Lovely fresh Crab, really enjoed getting stuck in, nice crusty bread, Mayo was a little pedestrian, would expect a home made product!Some lovely looking slip soles were a special on the night, looked very good.

4kVH3TBkUWJXFfK25ixA1Q.text: The fish stew was lovely. Oysters were fresh. Great bread accompaniment.It's a bit stuffy, I looked around and everything looked very dignified and stern, but it's a solid place for seafood. Just don't wear your sweats in here.

7ckuJaqHgVJg-79gvmMi1w.text: Excellent dining experience.  Just stumbled across this place near the theater district. Very pleased. All sorts of fresh seafood options. The pea soup prior and Welsh rarebit afterwards were both excellent.

j6RUAhXBmEjI-btjGSmnug.text: While the restaurant is known for it's seafood, I also want to add for all of the vegetarians out there that J Sheekey has a vegetarian menu if you ask for it. I had the Grilled Halloumi & Dukkah Spiced Tenderstem Broccoli with harissa dressing and it was one of the best dishes I have had in quite a few years. I also started with an Asparagus and Tortillini soup that was delicious as well. The friends I was with had seafood entrees and they had nothing but good things to say as well. The service was excellent but the menu is a bit pricey. But you're in London in the theater district so that is to be expected. If I have to say anything negative it would be that we never had one waiter for our table. It seemed that three or four people checked in on us, so I was confused as to whom to speak with if I had a question. Still, on my next trip to London, I'll return to j Sheekey.

YWdKrJo-jknw0L9No51CTA.text: My guide to stars is:3 = good4 = I will go out of my way to return5 = flawlessThis is why I gave J Sheekey a three. It was fab, but I didn't see myself going out of my way to go there again. Until I realized that I'd been talking about it quite a bit over the last few months. It has been a year and I figure I'm due for another death by seafood, so I'm going to make reservations as soon as I hit "Post."

qBmRGk9pQn-lCS15xf7GEA.text: Service was superb and the food was extremely good. I would suggest making a reservation. My girlfriend loved the fish pie and I was extremely satisfied with everything. Try the prawns, they melt in your mouth.

hAx5W3eRMOUs3sCIe_fP7Q.text: The raw oysters were great but all other dishes seemed mediocre....and was quite pricey.  Not enough value for money here so won't be going back.

M8TaCJ11Qi2VdFHQ23LTbw.text: Amazing seafood! Fresh, tasty and cooked to perfection. We wanted to go to Scott's but this sister restaurant is quite good. Prices are relatively reasonable. Loved the oysters and razor clams. Make reservations. Would come back again.

ZKupa0InhJy3zXptYJO6rw.text: Excellent food, though depending where you come from in the world, you may find it a little pricey (especially the oysters, which at almost £4 each, are a little over priced). Still, exceptionally knowledgable staff, a great selection of fresh fish and seafood, and delicious flavour combinations.I had the Hake with chorizo and sautéed octopus. Unbelievably good.The only negative was the pace of service. Too slow.

gq6iJDtRKzSzxTC5PkuYhQ.text: Meh. Sorry to report that this place was not very good and really was a disappointment. Service was comically slow and really atrocious. We had high expectations as this place was recommended by the concierge at Claridges Hotel who is normally spot on. Food was not bad as we had a number of different items off the Oyster Bar menu, which is tapas style, ordered three separate times. However the dishes came out slowly and in the wrong order. In fact the first thing we ordered was the last to come out.  To top it off we were asked to move inside as they were closing up the outside dining area due to the late hour. If they had served us properly we'd have been long gone by that point. The bass ceviche was excellent and the star of the show.  But you can do better for seafood in London.

JY-NBIA5xeGdKyEC-Aig8w.text: Us japanese love the seafood restaurant,but  it's little bit difficult to find a good seafood restaurant in EU. Here in London, it's very easy to find a  good seafood restaurant.Reserve the table at J Sheekey Ｏyｓｔｅｒ bar.　Of course oyster iｓ very good. We order the Lobster without　ｍayonnaise.That's nice too. I recommend this resutaurant to anybody.

h1ITOvm9bbF4qsRB3YzCZw.text: Lovely restaurant in St Martins Court. Within the depths of the theaters and with Oyster Bar written on the side facade, this place is quite an establishment.Service:Service here is rather fascinating, as there are some negatives for such a restaurant along with the overall professionalism. One incident was when one of the waiters served us the adjacent table's wine on top of our table's wine. It was even more interesting that the waiter never mentioned the mistake to either table. Otherwise it was pretty quality minus the above and a few other minor incidents.Venue:Dimly lit by candlelight, but the expectations for more intimate conversations were never met as the place was loud. Seating is very closely packed. Everywhere in London is typically tightly packed, but this felt just that bit more than others. So expect to be at arms reach of the other table's bread bowl.Food:Oysters - Porthilly RocksClean oysters. Accompanying sauces also provided a nice citrus kick or slightly spicy kick.Smoked Haddock with horseradish mash, poached egg and whole grain mustardQuite a good dish overall, but I'm a sucker for poached eggs on almost anything. The flavor of the fish itself wasn't on display as the mustard and the yolk over powered everything. It wasn't a bad thing as I really enjoyed the dish.Virunha Chocolate CakeDeep chocolate flavor. Must have for chocolate lovers. But if you're looking for something else then the pear tart is what to get, which apparently was absolutely delicious.Wine:Quite a nice wine list. We picked the Cuvée Tradition 2012, Les Filles de Septembre, Côtes de Tongue. A nice wine that is mild in nature and a small hint of spice.Even with the service miscues and the pricey menu, I found the place very good and really enjoyed my time there.

Ct481P81ERJbPO2Hq8eZuw.text: Hmmm, I'm definitely going against the curve here. I wish it would have been a four or a five star experience, but alas it certainly wasn't.Every time I visit my sister and her family in London they take me out to a nice dinner. It's a pretty good trade. This year I suggested seafood and they got us a reservation here at J Sheekey. I was excited reading about it, but once I got there the feeling evaporated.My partner and I arrived a bit before my sister and her husband. I checked in at the host's stand and preemptively said we would wait in the bar until the rest of our party had arrived. I've worked in restaurants for years, I know how it works. Anyhow, the maitre d insists we go ahead and take our table. We oblige. My sister and her husband get caught up in traffic and we are waiting there for over 40 minutes and not even once did a member of the waitstaff (who were ALL OVER the other tables) even offer us a drink or acknowledge we existed. Sure, they were all over us once the rest of the party arrived, but we both felt so awkward from the experience that there really was no bouncing back. Snooty, snooty, snooty. The food was good, this is true. But not better than many other seafood restaurants I've been to. Certainly not worth putting up with the poor service. The decor seemed incredibly dated to me as well. Some people call that an "institution". I call it time to remodel. Pass

5--fEq2WsAZX6GxGyD8LJw.text: Have been wanting to dine here for years and finally stopped in on last visit to London. Loved it - staff was attentive, our table location was a quiet nook, and the food was really, really delicious. Only knock is the server's heavy Russian(?) accent - I couldn't understand most of what was said, which was disappointing. However, can't  wait to go back!

a21jtaP8DqSduCgp_h82IQ.text: There's two connected but separate businesses here, the bar and the restaurant.  The service was first-rate fine-restaurant attentive, and the dinner was quick so I had no trouble at all making my evening show, so I regret to say that the food was more variable.  The soup (the variety of which changes regularly) was excellent, and I was very happy to have parmesan fried courgettes, a side I like but can rarely find, especially not at a fine restaurant.  My fish, however, was less than ideal.  Though a single fillet, it seemed divided into three layers, the top and bottom of which were well cooked while the middle one seemed intentionally underdone.  And it was resting on a bed of mashed potato, which the menu had not revealed, though it mentioned the other accompaniments.  I dislike potato, so this was an annoyance.  Pretty good meal, but I've had better in London.

k4CgFrbnryKdOm__PPTqKg.text: My wife and I went in and sat at the bar.    We had a sampling of oysters, squid, prawns etc.     service was exemplary.   Food was exquisite.    Highly recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom

ki1cJfW9Ba7NrYGWOePU5w.text: I heard it can be difficult to get a table during prime dinner time at J Sheekey, but my friend is a regular and they make exceptions for her.  Thus I occasionally have the privilege of tagging along to bathe in the top notch service.The dining room has an old school steakhouse vibe, however, the menu is anything but.  Fish is their speciality and they do it well here.  The tuna tartare is artfully presented and delicious - a must if you're doing a multi-course meal.  But otherwise, the entrees are well-portioned and will leave you sufficiently stuffed.  I appreciate that their menu changes seasonally and they have market specials which is what I order every time.  This probably isn't a place that you'd eat at everyday, but a solid choice for taking parents out to dinner, etc.

xtuzo98lGP3kOp9m4Qgq1w.text: Great food, I was just turned off that the server sat us by the bar said he was going to seat us when a table became available and never did. We spent over 180$ like nothing, I would just expect better service in the future. Although the food is good. This is a place you have to dress well for seems like they only serve people they deem worthy. I Recommend the food though if you don't mind spending.

photos.caption: Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate cake
Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom. Beet salad
Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom. Vodka

V9wIhw3qsIjlcHMK51aaGg.text: We were looking for a seafood restaurant close to where we were staying for our first meal in London, so we ended up making a noontime reservation at J Sheekey. It is centrally located to a lot of theaters in the West End, so perhaps unsurprisingly, the first question we were asked is if we had a time limit to meet to make a show. Since we didn't, it did allow us to enjoy the atmosphere of the restaurant a bit more, and to be honest, I found it quite nice - despite the low ceilings, the floor layout is a bit asymmetric, allowing for spacious seating and  enough room to make the seating feel cozy without resorting to NYC-levels of closeness. The service was a bit on the leisurely side, but everything came out in a well-spaced manner, although being next to the dumbwaiter was pretty fun...had never seen one of these food 'elevators' in action up close.The food...well, to be honest, my assessment went down as the meal went down, with the main course unfortunately being noticeably worse than the rest of the meal. We started out with some oysters to share, which were solid if unspectacular - the Natives were the my favorite with a clean and relatively smooth finish, but we were told the other two were similarly briny - not the case (one was extremely briny, with the others being of medium salinity). Additionally, the jalapeño-infused mignonette seemed like a good idea, but it was a bit strong on the nose and made it hard to really enjoy the flavor of either the mignonette or the oyster. Next up was the crab bisque (for me) and the truffle artichoke soup (for my wife). I liked hers better - it had stronger flavors - and while I did enjoy the bisque, the marginal amount of crab meat actually in it was disappointing. The mains are hard to explain, though, given the passable nature of the rest of the meal. My filet of cod was ridiculously undercooked...probably because the cut of the fish was way too thick. Eating undercooked cod with no flavor is just...not good at all. No amount of risotto (served under it) helped on that front. My wife's seafood stew was served out of a copper pot and looked promising, but it was devoid of any kind of salt, giving the broth a very flat tomato flavor that didn't even infuse any of the seafood into it.We skipped dessert because we were full (we were champs and ate most of the food, although I had to leave about half of my cod untouched). While the start of the meal was okay, the entrees were highly disappointing, and after seeing the bill come out to ~150 pounds...well, it's hard for the math to add up to a high rating. I enjoy the ambiance, and location is nice if you are going to a show, but I would definitely seek out another place if you are looking for a seafood-oriented meal first.

677MKgkA8DByVReV0m0JdA.text: We ate in the Atlantic Bar and I really don't understand what the hype is about. Is it just that it is close to the theatre? The food was only fair. The sashimi starters were OK, nothing special. The octopus was fairly tasteless, the razor clams with chorizo should have been amazing but they were disappointing with starter sized portions. The banoffee cheesecake and the cheese were the best parts of the meal. We won't be back.

_nd9wSSS2m20bGX9UAeAqg.text: Absolutely the BEST seafood dining experience EVER!! Started with Chilled Chowder and also the tomato salad - scrumptious!!!!!Had to have the signature Fish Pie - also amazing!Equivalent to the quality of the food was the exceptional service - from the arrival through departure. A 12 on a scale of 10!

photos.caption: Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom. j Sheeky - London

VUppgVUDzSxsSqRFHiv3sQ.text: Delightful seafood restaurant right in the middle of the theater district in London.  It is steps away from the tube stop and is nestled into a small alley.  It offers both in and outdoor dining.This is an old school experience with precision service and delicious but simply prepared food.  This is a top spot for dining in London.

photos.caption: Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom. Maggie Smith as a young woman!

ErV1yhDlBWNyYT9MKjBWXQ.text: Good food but very slow service. We also were seated about thirty minutes past our reservation. One of those meals where we had to constantly try to track down a server to ask a question or order something. Besides that, I thought my salmon was good quality but not very unique. My husband loved the lobster thermidor. I also loved the apple dessert with custard. Not sure I would come back because of slow service, but had no complaints about the food.

photos.caption: Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom. Lobster thermidor - excellent!
Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom. Apple dessert with custard drizzled on top- very good!
Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom. Salmon was good but nothing special

ilAr7gt15hpdrVzJgl7kpw.text: Amazing seafood alert!!!! I have been on a low fat low carb diet for the last few weeks in order to lose the extra fat i have accumulated by overeating fantastic food. Needless to say, it's quite hard to find a restaurant which fits the diet (and where I would not get tempted by fries or other fried deliciousness). I went there last week with the BF and we loved it!! We ordered a plateau de fruits de mer for 2 and it was heaven!! (I have previously posted picture of it, it looks like food porn!!) Also the waiter was knowledgeable about the food and also the wine to go with it (and he answered so quickly to "which wine goes best with this ?"  that I ordered a bottle of the said delicious white wine -I know it doesn't fit the diet, but you only live once and it was fab!!)We ate most of it - to our waiter's amazement; he wouldn't believe that I, a size 10/12 young woman could eat so much... (Guess why I am on a diet :/) i could have explained to him that seafood is very good for you, it's lean and the only fat it has is full of omega 3 and so on but I kept on eating my langoustine instead :) Even the mayonnaise - I had to try it- was nice, my dad makes a very similar one with just a bit mor pepper in it. (And of course, my dad's mayonnaise is the best one in the whole world) To sum up : great food, great wine, great service! Num num num!! I'll be back soon!!!

photos.caption: Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom
Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom
Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom

8dBZoi4pUsRmO0PCFlXeLg.text: The seafood here is delicious and I doubt you can go wrong with any pick. We started with some chilled Atlantic prawns, which were super fresh. I regretted only getting a quarter pint! For the main entree, I had the fish stew and the BF had the fish pie. The fish stew had an assortment of seafood, including mussels, scallops, shrimp, fish, and was really rich and savory. On the other hand, I didn't like the fish pie. I think it was the texture and consistency of the fish that I didn't like. I ended up eating just the mashed potato inside. If you like seafood and want something a little more upscale, this is a good try!

photos.caption: Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom
Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom
Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom

A96mN3s2Wevb1DsoJIxl7A.text: Really very nice indeed. Although the menu suggests "meat dishes also available" you're pretty much in the wrong place if you don't like fish or shellfish. The old school, dark wood interior does not detract from what is a thoroughly modern restaurant, that nonetheless has not lost touch with its roots. Front of house is generally efficient and polite - after booking on line, I had a slight worry when I was called three times in one ten minute period about confirming my booking. All, seemingly, by the same person. Never mind; even mid week, this place was buzzing, but not so crammed that we had to wait when we did turn up ( twenty minutes early).Starters run around the £12-17 mark; we had razor clams , and octopus with pink fir potatoes. Immaculate. Mains, skate for me, cod for my wife, ditto immaculate. With dessert, a decent bottle of Albariño and coffee, the bill came to around £200. But then, to somewhat paraphrase Anthony Bourdain, why would bargain seafood be a good idea?

fii3L2x4EmfYaBI7_Y7BEQ.text: Hidden in the Piccadilly circle, this place s not easily located. It turned out worthy when the food were brought out. Decently plated and beautifully cooked octopus made my night. The oysters were a bit pricey but tasted really fresh. It was in general a good experience after the Harry Potter show.

hjPsW8CM-UMeAwBxEXTXMw.text: When you get terrible service it's disconcerting. Is this just extreme incompetence or some kind of personal attack? Anyway, I asked the J Sheekey host if I could walk in. Wasn't a problem on the casual side so they seated me. And went out of their way to ignore me. I think I could have had a stroke and they wouldn't have talked to me. I left. 0% J Sheekey in 250 years or whatever you haven't learned to make sure everyone is polite??

mL2rbouu69o-B9eGTPZDlw.text: Didn't have the best service here, but I think that's a London thing. We had to grab our waiter for everything, it was even a pain finding someone to grab the check for us.But besides that the food was pretty good. I got the fried fish. It was really tasty, only wish the portion was a little bigger

photos.caption: Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom. Fried fish

3CebMzvIRWROGegANyyaTg.text: The best sea food I've ever tasted! Full house is a good choice. Truly recommend for a dinner with friends. Nice environment.

photos.caption: Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom
Photo of J Sheekey - London, United Kingdom

J2N2J6SaCzc2ej21-DvxZQ.text: Great place, great food, great service, etc. in a very touristy spot. It hey it's London. It's not modern or anything innovative. But it was great food and everything they did was spot on. Try some of the interesting stuff on the menu. We ordered fish roe on toast (mackerel I think?) and it was great. I had the razor clams app and it was great. Definitely a destination if visiting London...

1I7kYA3Es3dsrbK1ThtyRA.text: We totally enjoyed this place.  The seafood was incredibly incentive and every flavor carefully designed and executed.

c3a1kOWafCtBwYJS995r-g.text: This is the third time I have been to J. Sheekey.  This will be the last time. Considering the high prices and hard to get tables, one would at least expect top notch food and fine service. Instead you get a bored staff (does anyone smile in this joint) and truly mediocre food. The crab bisque was totally flat, the risotto was bland, and the monk fish and prawns were something you could honestly get at TGIF. We skipped dessert, as we just wanted to leave.  Some long run restaurants lazily coast on their reputations, while others always seek to remain consistently excellent and strive for the best. J. Sheekey is a coaster and will most likely remain one for its next 100 years. It's a shame.

Ll_GG0l4qzEc6R4XWbnEgQ.text: Sat at the new Oyster bar.  Great feel to the restaurant.   Great service.  Very old-school, but they do it well.

8Jk_Xyv4IstRvYznXPNRoQ.text: J. Sheekey was quite a delight. I took my uncle there as he loves seafood. We had lobsters for main course which was really a treat! No complain about the food at all. The taste was just great; desert took a little while to arrive at our table but generally we came out happy. The bill was a little on the high side though, the was about 200 for 3 person and we didn't even had alcohol.It very much like an 'English old coin' if I have to put an analogy against it. Hence, it kept my uncle satisfied!

766nLCMAx4GAF7QVmFBGPg.text: The razor clams were highly recommended. Table next door had the fruits de mere that was the biggest serving of seafood I have ever seen! Only complaint was that they tried to squeeze six of us onto a tiny table.

I0B0BnLNhuxutKzXcmbDRQ.text: Tables are far to close to each other so don't come here for a discrete meal. The fish is always fresh and well prepared stick to simple dishes like dressed crab and a dover soul meuniere and you will not be disappointed. The wine list is good if on the expensive side. I cannot think of many better fish restaurants in London.

0TYWFf4jLulPUSvW_gnCTQ.text: Oh, J Sheekey, it really kills me to have to write a not-glowing review for you. My last experience was so horrid that I would give it 2 stars based solely on that but due to previous positive experiences (that could have earned it 4, if not 5 stars) I will give it 3 stars. Prior to my last visit I had only ever visit with my parents, i.e. adults. I distinctly felt that my boyfriend and I were not treated with as much respect merely because of our age (24 and 25). We were treated rudely and pretty much ignored. Our waiter mocked our orders. My boyfriend ordered two salads (one was a typical lettuce-based salad and another a lobster-based salad) and I just wanted an assortment of shellfish like oysters and prawns. I know this may not be typical, but I don't think it merited mocking. In fact, I don't know if it's ever right to mock people when they're paying you for your services. I also am not familiar with prawns as they are not the norm in the states (shrimp cocktails are) and I wanted to know the difference between the two offered and the waiter acted as if it were the most ridiculous and trying fete he'd ever encountered. At this point, I was ready to ask to speak to the manager when we left, but our service greatly improved as the night went on. Unfortunately, our meal did not. I got food poisoning from my oysters and was ill throughout the entire night and morning. The one great thing they do have going for them still in my mind is that they are very accommodating when it comes to pre- and post-theatre dinners.

HBB5oFSheUgu9CwG4tqA1Q.text: Other than sushi, I'm not a huge seafood eater. If you are, this place is the nuts. This was my second dinner of the night (had just finished a tasting menu an hour earlier) so I wasn't very hungry. I had the tomato salad and split the grilled turbot for two with béarnaise sauce. Both were very good. The béarnaise sauce was amazing, it was thicker, almost a butter consistency, and made the dish great. The butternut squash side dish is the best I've had. I also had some of the creamed cauliflower soup with oxford blue cheese and walnuts. London makes the best veggie soups. For all of you struggling veggie eaters, the soups here make it so easy to get your daily suggested servings. It was only an hour long dinner break for my husband (poker tournament) so we didn't have time for dessert, but I assume it would have been amazing.anitaeat.com

BmRg87qlK_TUWARQ61TMgw.text: Delicious food.  This feels like a sort of proper old school steakhouse (dark food interior, photos of actors on the walls, prompt pretentious professional servers) but serving fish...  Lovely oysters, great mains.  Lovely service.  Would recommend.

0iw7QNsLerKtQZAK2cGyeQ.text: I had lunch at J Sheekey in April 2011 as I was told it had a very good fish selection. The atmosphere in J Sheekey (which is just tucked around the corner from Leicester Square tube station) is one of understated elegance and you can tell it's going to be a place with good, discrete service.The menu did indeed have a large selection of fish and shellfish and I opted for the somewhat traditional haddock and chips and mushy peas with some shared sides of steamed spinach and broccoli.The waitress informed us that our mains would take 20 mins (since we had not ordered a starter) which was helpful I thought.When the food arrived, it was well presented and all parties were served simultaneously. The fish was battered and crisp outside but moist inside, the chips crispy too and the mushy peas very green and smooth! Overall the food was excellent but what was even more impressive was the dessert! I wanted the double-choc souffle but due to time constraints (it takes about 20 mins to prepare) I had a vanilla Creme Brulee. This was one of the nice slim, wide dishes not the small deep dishes (which means you get short-changed on all that sugary topping!) It was really nice and tasty and scooping down into it revealed vanilla seeds at the bottom of the dish, which was pretty clever. I had half before I was stuffed and my colleague fiinished off the rest.All in all, yummy, good service, not too pricey (about £30 per head) but not cheap either, but worth every penny!

OrAKNKrKetMKxUI7zQlzjQ.text: Went in the other day for there glass of champagne and 6 oysters deal. FANTASTIC. Oysters were all fresh, (the attendent smelled eveyone after opening then), although a tad small and the champagne was more than palatable. Lovely surroundings and very friendly staff. Highly recommended.

l8eLlqT1WPXplYpYVZhKGw.text: Simple a straight forward oyster bar.  Had lunch here on a saturday.  While the service was slow sitting at the bar becaue there is only one chef and the waiters are busy preparing for the evening crowd, it is nice to watch the chef doing his craft behind the bar.  I would be curious to see how this place is at night because it has more of a dinner feel than a lunch one.

l7Q--6R3dQHX7XWm54Iwqw.text: The perfect pre (or post) theatre dining restaurant. Service is swift and West End openings are listed on the back of your menu so that you will not miss the crucial curtain raise. Food is pricey but top notch with oysters galore and buttery folds of smoked salmon. Yes it is expensive but eating here with all the old thespians beaming down from their photographs on the wall is part of the whole theatre experience.

fcBWBVaGOF4Up8t4obt6pQ.text: Utterly amazing, some of the best food I have ever eaten. Faultless....

5tmX3gQta6XBf0LrwI67VA.text: Went on the recommendation of friends. Had a lovely meal with excellent service. The dining area is split into smaller more intimate areas which was nice. Thoroughly enjoyed the food but it wasn't exceptional. I would go back for lunch and would go for dinner again but not for a special occasion.

YkZtd8trc9W77qLTWcTGTg.text: Excellent if pricey fish restaurant which is best enjoyed occasionally to remind you of the better things in life. I have been twice and enjoyed the slightly pretentious, if laissez faire atmosphere. Despite this the service is suitably attentive and i look forwards to returning when i feel flush enough. Good wine list to boot.

qIm8eoTc5hBZiU9psV8Uew.text: If you are a fish lover then you will love this place. Some gorgeous fresh fish to be had here in comfortable surroundings. Part of the group that own the Ivy I believe, but it's not so glamorous as it's sister restaurant. We've been a few times for a pre-theatre dinner and service was swift and efficient. Maybe not so good to go at this time if you're not going to the theatre judging by one of the reviews on here, but I would still recommend it for great fish anyway.

vWRN5LVvqwRDxaUlRqNovg.text: At the third time of trying, my wife and I finally got to eat here. This time, as it was my wife's 30th birthday, I played safe by booking three months in advance! It was well worth the wait. We ate late (after Wicked) and despite this the restaurant was busy. The seating is a little tight but I really didn't find that an issue. The staff were really friendly and the service was great: the somelier helped with an excellent choice of wine for our food and seemed to be both at our table topping up our glasses whenever needed but at the same time unobtrusive. The food justified its price and they were even adept at cardiopulmonary resuscitation techniques when rather embarrasingly I had a heart attack whilst viewing the £170 bill. Actually, one of my most memorable dining experiences.

AOW206FQNGl7Rxthh2o0pQ.text: Visiting London for the day - looking for a quality seafood restaurant before we left. Arrived with plenty of time to spare before heading off for our train. On arrival to a fairly empty restaurant we were asked if 'we were attending the theatre this evening.' We correctly replied that we weren't and thought no more of this inoquous question. The starters arrived, which were nice, but then time seemed to stand still on our table. People arrived, ordered and were served - not just one course but two or three - whilst we sat waiting for our main course. It took nothing short of a complaint to ensure our main course arrived before we absolutely needed to walk out for our train. They still felt the need to offer deserts, rather than a timely bill, and load said bill with all those nonsense charges like 'table cover' AND 'service charge'. Needless to say we had those removed pronto before dashing for our train. Our advice to anyone considering this restaurant based on it's reputation is to consider your own plans for the evening and lie through your teeth if need be, because theatre goers seem to be the be-all-and-end-all when it comes to customer service.

dd-KtEgQ_zXxx9o6KxufOA.text: I felt like I HAD to comment on J Sheekey after reading some of the reviews below. J Sheekey is a  famous, well established seafood restauraunt in Covent garden/Leic Sq.Kate Moss often used to quote in many a magazine interview that it was her 'fave' place to eat in London.The Fish pie is what people tend to rave about here, the piece de resistance and indeed when I ate here, I thought it was fabulous too.The interior at Sheeky's is very cosy, all luxorious leather banquets rich red velvet drapes and gold gilt  trimmed tables.Hence,, do dress up a bit -don't wear your cosy clothes! (No trainers etc) .As with most of the high end, high profile places to eat  in London, if you wish to eat before 8PM or after 10.30PM, even on a weekend- the likelihood is, you will get a table.Mainly because most people in London don't eat out before 7.30 or after the latter! Secondly, often if you call to book ON THE DAY when you want to reserve, you may find that due to a last minute cancellation, there is a table free.It's well worth a try, give them a call!

x7KV82dhcPAmwVMX2KtrQQ.text: We found this place with qype app on our new ipad. Qype reviews pulled us here very correctly. Yes 6 oysters and champagne is "the" choice here, we added steamed mussels and muscadet which turned the whole experience to a feast. Thumbs up!

RgSVYi4LeIeNWPoroHTjQQ.text: great place to go with pals!!!! yummy cocktails!!!!
